This anime is pretty average, but I really enjoyed it. I'd recommend watching the first episode and seeing if you like it.

Plot (7): The magical academy setting has been done before, but not every anime has to come up with something super innovative as long as it is done well. It starts off with the cliché "male MC accidentally enters a room with the female MC changing" trope. However, unlike most male MCs who freak out, Ikki tried to rectify the situation with a rather... interesting tactic. I was kinda scared that the anime will go overboard with the ecchi-ness, especially after Episode 2. However, the anime really started to pick up for the 3rd and 4th episodes. I liked how the romance between Ikki andStella progressed. It was not too fast nor was it too slow. I have noticed that Silver Link decided to take some liberties by shuffling the material around a bit compared to the manga and LN. For instance, the romance between Ikki and Stella was pushed earlier, though I can see why SL thinks the move was justified: to make the romantic sub-plot more continuous. I didn't mind the idea of shuffling things around, but the execution could've gone better. The Sword Eater arc has been very engaging as it managed to keep me interested in Ayase. Episode 7 uses the often utilized "the power of friendship" trope, but it's the execution that counts and it was executed extremely well. Episode 8 attempts to develop Ayase's character a bit more, but it wasn't that much as most of it was Ikki vs. Kuraudo. The plot has been good, but not great. However, I thought Episode 9 did a really great job advancing the romance between Stella and Ikki. While the anime did modify the plot from the LN, it did a decent job. It was a bit rushed, though. Episode 10 is the first time where a supporting character gets the spotlight and Silver Link did not disappoint. Episode 11 goes back to focusing on Ikki (and Stella) and SL did a good job advancing their development. The last episode did a good job concluding the show where the first half is dedicated to some more Ikki development.


Art (9): Character designs aren't original, but again, as long as it is done well, I'm okay with that. The color palette and backgrounds have this "pop" that is really appealing to the eye. One very good example would be the pink petals of the Japanese maple trees in Episode 2. The anime has also done a good job using a variety of color palettes and backgrounds such as the dark and dull blizzard in Ikki's flashback. The animations, however, are what takes the cake here. This is especially true in Episodes 3 and 4. They are very clean and use different angles effectively. I also liked, in Episode 5, how Silver Link used animations in a comedic way when the sparkles suddenly disappear when the guys freaked out at Nagi (Alice) Arusuin posing in his swimsuit. The animations show their strength in fight scenes again in Episode 7 and 8, utilizing a variety of angles and color palettes. As for Episode 10... holy crap. I can say that it was the zenith. The animations were intense and dynamic. Superbly done. Episode 11 takes a very interesting route by having the artstyle correlate with the mood and I thought it was done well. While Episode 12 wasn't as risque as the previous episode, it still use some variety in artstyle. The fight, while brief, was animated very well, too.


Sound (8): The soundtrack does a very good job at enhancing various moments, whether they be action scenes or romantic scenes. There is a good variety in the instrumentation, ranging from predominantly percussion to a string orchestra with a classical guitar soloist. Certain tracks are reused, but they are spaced out well enough so that they still sound fresh. Episode 7 is a perfect example of how reused tracks are utilized effectively. They did a really good job at enhancing the atmosphere and emotions of various scenes. I stated earlier that I hoped that the anime added some new tracks to keep the old tracks fresh. Thankfully, Silver Link has done that. However, a few tracks have been used a bit too much.


The opening song is very upbeat and perfectly fits with the theme of the anime. I was initially "meh" on the ending song. My feelings towards the ED are still pretty neutral, but it's not so bad.


Characters (8): Initially, nothing home to write about in this department (originally a 7), but I thought this aspect gradually improved later on. The main characters fit in the archetypes that have been already used in lots of other anime. Stella is the pink-haired tsundere who initially dislikes the male protagonist because he accidentally peeped on her. However, unlike other tsunderes, the "dere" is more dominant than the "tsun". In fact, in the anime, Stella is even less "tsun" than her manga counterpart. In Episode 9, she is surprisingly quite forward with Ikki at advancing their relationship even further. I am so glad that Ikki isn't the immensely dense male protagonist that annoys me to no end in other anime. I like how he tried to take it upon himself to make things even with Stella after he accidentally peeped on her even though it was goofy. In Episode 6, his head got smashed by a glass bottle and Kuraudo spat on his face as insult to injury, but he kept his cool extremely well. That's the kind of patience I highly admire. I've noticed some people have criticized Ikki for being "Jesus-kun" or ass-pulling. However, this is quite false. Episode 8 showed how he can get very into the heat of battle. Episode 9 showed how Ikki isn't OP and unbeatable.


The other two characters, Shizuku and Alice are also pretty good. Shizuku was pretty hard to figure out, at first. Was she actually romantically infatuated with her brother or was she trying to compensate for Ikki's family's mistreatment of him? Or is there another reason altogether? You will find the answer in Episode 11. She also got good character development in Episode 10.


Alice really reminds me of Jann from Valkyria Chronicles. I really liked his interactions with Shizuku and Kagami. He has also played a significant role to Ikki's development. However, despite his motherly character, there was one tiny instance where he portrays coldness. I will leave you guys to figure out when he does that.


Kobayashi did a really great job playing as Ayase. Episodes 6 and 7 showcased her incredible range. In just those two episodes, we see a large variety of emotions, from shyness to manipulative sadism to desperation to sadness. As for Ayase's background, she is quite relate-able to Ikki whether they are both swordsmen or had an extremely difficult past. Nothing groundbreaking, but the portrayal of Ayase was very decent overall.


I will talk more about Touka as the next episodes air, but man, what an entrance! Her fight against Shizuku further reinforces her bad-assery. However, in Episode 11, she has a clumsy, but motherly character.


Enjoyment (9): Rakudai Kishi no Chivalry's action scenes are really fun to watch. While they are its strongest points, in my opinion, it doesn't mean the other aspects are lacking. The romance has progressed nicely and the anime does a great job with the comedy. The ecchi-ness, for the most part, is kept in check. At times, it goes overboard. There was one time where Silver Link thought it was funny to add some wardrobe malfunction to a certain scene in Episode 2 whereas it didn't happen in the manga. That's a really cheap and lazy way to gain some laughs, but thankfully, that was only one time and it happened early. Episode 9 was a good example of fanservice done right, in my opinion. It was not out of context and it was funny.


Overall (NOT an average of scores of the 5 specific categories) (8): It's a very fun anime to watch. The artstyle, sound, and animations are well done. It has a healthy dose of comedy, action, and romance. The characters, while encompassing generic archetypes, are decent thanks to good development and interactions. Despite appearing to be a harem, it is actually not. I think the quality is decent enough to warrant a 2nd season.

I don't usually watch these types of anime because they seem so generic and unoriginal and comparable with any other action/ecchi/school anime that exists, and there are A LOT. And this is because these types of shows don’t focus on a particular target market but have a bit of everything. Some people watch it for the romance, some for the battle scenes and others for the psychological battles and etc. And the real challenge of the show is how to find the right balance between romance and action so that the people who came for the romance scenes still watch when there's fighting going onand vice versa, which I think "Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry" manages to pull off fairly well compared to other shows of its kind.


I personally enjoyed the romance scenes a bit more than the action scenes because I felt that the fight scenes weren’t animated as well as the romance scenes. A personal pet peeve of mine is when there is too much talking going on during fight scenes in anime explaining everything that’s happening and Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry has a lot of this. It’s fine once in a while to explain fight scenes but when most of the fights are literally people talking and explaining the fights instead of properly showing and animating the fights, it seems really cheap and unenjoyable for people who came to watch the action scenes.


The story? You probably know the story by now; chances are that if you pull out any other anime with a magic school setting you'll actually get something very similar. But just because the show has a generic story, doesn’t mean it can’t be told very well, and as long as you’re someone who doesn’t mind all the tropes like tsundere, imouto, or overpowered gary stu MC’s with ridiculous plot armor, then you’ll probably enjoy the show. 


If there’s another reason to watch the show, it’s the opening. Some people overlook openings because they really have nothing to do with the actual show but a good opening sequence like this one can really make a show more enjoyable watching and also entice people to watch it.  


Character development is something I wish I’d have seen more of in this anime. There are SO MANY characters which they dump in the show literally just to create a trope and then disappear having almost no impact on the show. And with a show that already has a generic setting, it’s a bit disappointing that they don’t flesh out the characters a bit more so that they have more of an impact to the viewers.  


Overall I found Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry fairly decent, it’s better than most generic harem-ish anime with magic school settings but it’s still just a generic harem-ish anime with a magic school setting.

After reading the synopsis, you might be thinking this is yet another magic-school fantasy centered around an overpowered male lead. You're not wrong. You also might be imagining a relatively shallow and overused plot and...you're probably right on that account too. But if you think Kurogane Ikki is the oblivious one dimensional protagonist you're used to seeing, you're dead wrong.
Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is easily one of this season's best productions and a wonderfully refreshing addition to the harem genre. Scratch that. This isn't a harem, but it certainly feels like one for the first few episodes. Does this mean we finally have a protagonistwho has the balls to choose a girl??? Indeed he does and early on in the show too. As a consequence, we as anime viewers actually get the rare opportunity to see how a relationship progresses beyond the confession stage. Imagine that. 


Here, the romance between Ikki and Stella definitely deserves much praise. The writers and producers did a great job fleshing them out as characters and paced their relationship appropriately. Like any couple, they have real arguments and issues which they talk over. The producers don't even shy away from the blatantly obvious sexual tension that is often dismissed in ecchi shows . Instead, these sexual issues are actually confronted in some of the conversations that Ikki and Stella share, making them more like a real couple. 


Thus, I found the show's strongest point to be its characters and their relationships. I'm not just referring to the romance between the leads but also to the relationships between all the characters. You feel as though you understand where these characters are coming from and why they are fighting so desperately to win. They aren't doing it just to prove that they're strong. 


Ikki certainly doesn't. He fights to prove a greater message - that hard work can match or even exceed natural talent. Easily the show's most likable character, Ikki only seems "overpowered" because he gives every fight his 100% and trust me, he doesn't win by whipping out a new ultra-powerful technique for every fight. This makes him less like a character and more like a person - someone you can stand behind and root for because you know he's trying his very best to match his opponents. 


By the way,  this show has some of the best action sequences I've seen in recent years. They're thrilling and have a tendency to keep you on the edge of your seat because the action is incredibly fast paced. Instead of standing around and conversing, most of the dialogue occurs within the character's minds during a fight. In other words, we witness how they're analyzing the battle as they're constantly moving. If that isn't impressive enough, Kotaro Nakagawa's incredible score will definitely keep your heart pumping through them. 


Still, Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry isn't without its flaws. Like I said, the plot isn't anything new and basically identical to that of another magic-school anime this season, The War of Asterisk. Furthermore, I felt as though Stella started off as a strong female lead who was unnecessarily developed into a more feminine one as the show went on. The ending leaves many things unanswered but I can't complain because it follows the source material exactly and we can only hope for a second season. 


Overall, this anime is worth a watch for anyone who wants to have a good time. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes romance, magic-sword fights, and the occasional dose of fan-service. For those of you who are turned off by the show's generic plot, watch until episode 4 and give the character development a chance to hook you. Don't let the synopsis fool you because Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is definitely not "The Worst One" in its genre.

Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is one of the most mixed experiences I've ever had in regards to anime and manga. Nothing about it is particularly great, in fact, I'd argue that most of its traits place it below average. Hell, the only reason I started the series was because I saw the opening on YouTube and thought it would be some kind of badass, gritty Western with samurai cowboys (The opening had a twangy, catchy tune and there were swords and the word "cavalry" was in the title. Don't judge me.)  Yet, I found myself enjoying the show greatly,despite the fact that it pretty much sucks. Is this one of those mythical "guilty pleasures" I've heard about? The answer is no, this anime won its favor with me on its own merits, but I don't think I would ever be able to reccomend this show to anyone looking for a good anime.\n
     Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry's main claim to fame is its romance. If you ask any fan of the show why you should watch it, they'll tell you "Its not a harem anime, its an actual romance!" and that will be it. I'm going to be brutally honest here, the romance of RKnC sucks, but those people do have a point. The chemistry between the leads (Ikki and Stella) is noteworthy, and there are some really realistic and sweet scenes between the two ("Why are we arguing?" "I don't know!"), but one of the key aspects of a good romance is actually having good characters. The characters in Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry are garbage. As a result of the characters being awful, the romance really doesn't hold any weight and can't technically be called good. That being said,  the dialogue between Stella and Ikki is very enjoyable and is definitely the best thing this anime has going for it.\n
    When I said that the characters were awful, I wasn't joking. Seriously, the leads consist of Ikki (Cliche harem protagonist who's saving grace is the fact that he isn't in a harem. He's also really overpowered despite being built up as weakling who sucks at magic.) and Stella (Starts out as nothing more than a tsunedere bitch, but loses those tsunedere qualities by the halfway point of the show. After aformentioned halfway point, she essentially has no standout character qualities to speak of. Tsunedere bitch > no standout qualities.). What's really sad is that the cast of side characters are all just as generic and, in some cases, outright disgusting. Shizuku, Ikki's little sister, is a white haired loli who wants to fuck her big bro. Classy. What's worse is that the anime tries to explain this disgusting behaviour through this big, tragic backstory of how she always looked up to her brother and just wanted to help him with his problems. The only thing worse than pedophilia is self-hating pedophilia that tries to justify its own perversion. Embrace the fuckery, damnit! Oh, and theres also a tranny named Alice who's somewhat of a sassy gay(?) mentor figure to Shizuku and others. Out of all the side characters in the series, the only one that I really liked was the final villain, Todo. She was this badass chick who was also really likeable and charismatic. On top of that, there writer(s) goes out the way to place parallels between Toda and Ikki. I honestly felt like she would have made a better protagonist than Ikki.\n
    The plot is awful as well. Threats are hyped up (student council is an example of this) and then totally disregarded. There's also this big subplot at the end of the series involving a hearing that doesn't make any sense whatsoever (Why the hell did Ikki go to the hearing and let himself be tortured? He literally did nothing wrong and had no reason, psychological or legal, to go. Kissing a rich, talented girl is not illegal last time I checked. So contrived.).\n
     So why do I like this series? Like I said, the romantic dialogue was good and realistic and Todo was beastly. Also, while the romantic plot is bad and the characters suck, the romance progresses at a pace that is pleasing, fulfilling, and unique. Also, the soundtrack (particularly dat opening) was fairly good. \n
     All in all, Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is a shitty series with some really fun aspects. I wouldn't reccomend it to anybody other than an experience fan of LN adaptations.\n
This is Horatio_Nelson, signing out.

Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is certainly one of the biggest surprises of 2015. For me, who never expects much from anime adaptations of magic school battle harem light novels, it completely caught me off guard since i went with little to no expectations at all and still was pleasantly surprised by how good Rakudai Kishi turned out to be. 
Unlike many other series of the same genre, Rakudai had the good fortune to receive a proper, non rushed adaptation that only covered 3 volumes of the source material. Unsurprisingly, the pacing never felt off and the original story wasn't butchered. It just felt right.
And talkabout a strong ending! I think this show improved immensely since episode 1 and now that it is finally over, it certainly makes you eager for more. I love how it so confidently managed to free itself from the usual LN battle harem formula and tired LN routines and actually ended up developing an identity of its own with some really likable main characters and some nice stylistic (director worked at Shaft with Shinbo) and artful visuals and top notch animation quality in pretty much every important fight. \n
And not just that: the romance is super refreshing and surpringly charming and mature for the genre since the two main kids are seriously likable and their interactions are genuinely honest and entertaining, so their chemistry is undeniable. The amount of progression in their relationship and how natural and healthy it feels in only just 12 episodes would put most romantic comedies to shame. \n
As for the story and setting, it is hardly original but still fairly entertaining. Since it mostly revolves around a battle tournament, it relies on the fight's quality and on the strenght of its characters and the interactions between them a lot more than other LN series, which would rather focus on overly complicated settings and boring worldbuilding with an unecessarily large scope and obnoxious technical slang, endless harem members and bland self-insert main characters that no one really cares about. \n
Luckily, Rakudai managed to overcome all these genre barriers and tropes, and that is why it stands so much in such a stale environment, clogged up with repeated ideas and lack of originality.\n\n
So should you watch Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry? Definitely.\n\n
All in all, and as far as LN adaptations go, this is undoubtedly a pretty good one and the original source is definitely way above average, so even though it starts fairly generic and it takes some time to get to the good stuff, you should definitely give it a try because you will probably enjoy it, even if it won't blow your mind. Moreover, there is also a very unusual sense of closure you don't often find in these sort of anime, which makes the whole thing even more satisfying while still leaving you eager for a second season.

Cliches in anime are something are commonly used for the sole purpose of pushing along the plot using an easy and well known way.  Things like the token meeting of the tsundere, the general overpoweredness of our main character, etc.  And so, we have "A Tale of the Worst One", a show that does a rather decent job at not following the herd.  (And that is a good thing.)
Story: Kurogane Ikki is known as the "Worst One", a noble knight (aka a person who wields a magical blade) who is Ranked F.  A student that is so bad that he hadto be held back for a year and is considered as the worst student in the entire school since he performs simply the worst.  (They really bully in the fact that he's the worst.)  One day however, he, by the laws of anime, is roomed up with the new student, an A-class rank who is also a princess, might I add, named Stella Vermillion, and sees her undressing, ladadadada (we've been over this in several hundred other series'), then...says that he'll strip so she doesn't feel like the only one embarrassed in the room.  Huh.  Well that's a new one.  


In essence, Rakudai Kishi is a show that follows your traditional tournament anime format.  The goal of the series is for Ikki, our main protagonist, that he is not the worst one, and does so by entering the national noble knights tournament, the "Seven Star Battle Festival", an even where each school sends in six students to participate; Ikki spends the entire show pretty much vying for one of these spots.  For the most part, that's our show.  But that's not what makes Rakudai better as a series.


What really makes this show is the fact that it doesn't fully rely on average tropes in order to make up episode to episode.  The most notable example of this is the romance that goes on in this show.  Romance in anime is generally either rushed to the point it makes no sense, or so dreadfully slow that you'd die before they even think about the thought of them being a couple.  Rakudai not only makes its main couple a definite fact, but it builds upon that.  Not as smoothly as it could've might I add, but it's not done in a way that feels completely out of place, and I like that.  


And so, with all of that being said, what is there wrong with the story if there're so many good things about it?  Well, my dear readers, one word can fully answer all of your questions.  Pacing.  (Pacing seems to be Silver Link's issue this season, as all of its shows have this kind of problem.)  Rakudai Kishi is a series that has a relatively good chunk of explanation or text behind it in order to explain how our protagonist does things in battle; that is not an anime's best friend.  Because of this, a lot of the technical parts of the show essentially get ousted to the point that what is happening on screen doesn't make sense, or at the very least, complete sense.  Not only that, but some rather important fights as well as some other key parts of the series aren't animated so there's a little bit of a disjointedness that they never really cover up.  Some parts don't go together as well as they should've, and that's the biggest shame of this adaptaion.


All in all, the story of Rakudai Kishi is solid, as we not only get one that breaks a couple trope breaking, but also one that has some decent storytelling.  However, because of the show's tendency to rush, it wasn't as great as I would've hoped and is honestly a bit of a disappointment seeing as how the other forms of the story are well received.  


Overview:

+  Decent story

+  Trope breaking scenes

-  Pacing issues create a whole host of other problems like missing story, rushed and/or missing explanations, and loss of key parts.)


Characters: Similar to its story, the cast for Rakudai Kishi does a fairly good job at breaking those lovely...lovely character tropes that we all know and love...  (I mean, everyone just loves a good tsundere, right?  ...Right?)  


Up first, we have Kurogane Ikki, the Worst One, as we're repeatedly reminded throughout the entire show without end.  (Seriously though, we get it.)  Even with all of this repeated abuse, Ikki remains as a strong and determined person who chooses actions rather than words, spending the entire series trying to prove to everyone that he's not the worst one by showing everyone his battle prowess and his ability to defeat enemies regardless of his limited abilities, which really shows a lot about his character.  He's a more relatable character that I feel makes the show better.  But, because of all of the shortcuts Silver Link took, we don't really get the full story.  


Then we have his partner, Stella Vermillion, the crown princess of the Vermillion kingdom, and the supposed 'token tsundere' of the series.  As the main female protagonist, Stella is the character that spends most of her time with Ikki and becomes closer to him as a result.  With this, we get a more natural progression (albeit a little rough due to the pacing) of a relationship between the two that eventually equates to something more and something that feels more genuine since the relationship between the two intertwines with the series.  Stella, like Ikki, feels more real as a character, but because of the lack of certain points, doesn't come out as well as she should've.  


As for other characters, we have Ikki's brocon imouto, Shizuku, her roommate Alice who is a guy who basically identifies as a female (not that there's anything wrong with that), Ikki's various opponents throughout the shows (some of which DON'T GET SHOWN!  ):<  ), the anemic teacher, the principal, etc.  For the most part, most of these characters serve as plot progression or help to explain what is going on, save for Shizuku and Alice who bear more importance to plot as they are main characters that add a lot more to the story.  Not as much as they should've, but they do.


Overview:

+ Good main characters and development

-  Side characters don't really have much importance to them

-  Pacing affected the impact of some characters and their importance


Art: The art for Rakudai Kishi is something of an interesting thing to tackle.  For the most part, the show is done in this light color palette that is rather standard in terms of quality.  Its fight scenes are rather fluidly done and they look nice, but there really isn't much to say because it's not fantastical in any way except for a few choice scenes.


Particularly in the OP and the second to last episode, Rakudai employs a black and white scheme reminiscent of old gangster films in a vintage filter that actually looked rather cool.  


Overview:

+ Cool Vintage style  (Even if only for one episode)

+/-  Relatively average artstyle.


Sound: The soundtrack for Rakudai Kishi is peculiar, to put it mildly.  The OP, known as "Identity" is a very fast-paced and action heavy music that has an oddly Spanish feel to it?  (Iunno.  It sounds a bit like Flamenco to me.)  It's a good OP, but for me, it doesn't really fit the series or the themes that Rakudai is trying to express.  Same for the ED, but the ED just sounds melancholy and uninteresting.  


Overview:

+ Good OP

-  Kind of meh ED

-  The music doesn't fit with the show


Personal Enjoyment:  Rakudai Kishi is one of the shows that I was excited for in the Fall 2015 season.  I read the manga and heard good things about the original LN, and I was hopeful of this adaptation that would come.  But in the end, we got something that was more based-on rather than adaptation.


Did I enjoy this series?


Admittedly, I still did liked this adaptation.  Forgetting all of the flaws, it was something that still was the series in a nutshell, focusing all of the more important parts of the series and not really the specifics.  


What didn't I like about the series?


Mostly, what angers me is the fact that the lack of proper pacing and explanation really brought the series down.  There's a lot of detail that is just absent and as a result, a lot of things felt a little disjointed and to a new viewer, could be confusing.  This might not seem like a big issue, but the written formats of this series are vastly different both in story and character to this anime.


Would I recommend this anime?


If you do know what happens in Rakudai, I would not recommend watching because they are missing a lot of things and some important fights/details are missing so...it might not be as enjoyable.  (I know I was upset when the cat girl didn't get her time in the spotlight.)  But if you haven't, then give it a shot.  It's a good series, but personally, I would say that this adaptation doesn't do it the justice that it deserves.

As someone who has watched many, many school battle harems over the years, I have started to grow dull to this type of show. At first I liked them, but as I kept watching the same recipe, the same characters, the same stories over and over again, I noticed that my enthusiasm to watch these anime started to fade.
Yet, in hope of finding one that would defy my low expectations, I kept watching every single one of them.
Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry seemed like one of these typical full-of-clichés shows. Just seeing the cover, I noticed the unoriginal lead girl in the front with red hairand twin-tails. Now I don't know if it fills an actual fetish but I have seen more red-hair twin-tails girls that I can remember and just from that I could already guess that she was going to be a tsundere as well. I was not mistaken. 


So I embarked on this 12-episodes journey that Tale of The Worst One was. 


The story started off with one of these overused cliché scenes where the male lead walks into a room and sees the female lead changing clothes. As to not spoil what happens next, I will keep quiet about what the male lead does. But what I can tell you is that the development of this scene actually pleased me.


The beginning of the shows does provide its audience with several clichés. But the way these are handled is usually different from other harem shows and one cannot help but feel refreshed at how the anime tries to make fun of these overused situations by breaking free of them in an unusual manner. For me, this was a big positive point.


Now although I would like to be as generous with the overall plot, I unfortunately have to admit that it's as generic as it can get in a magical/sci-fi school setting. There is a big tournament and our main characters have to take part into it for various reasons. It's already been done tons of times and will probably be done again in the future. It's uncreative but that's what the show's main audience enjoys so this setting is milked to the maximum.


The setting is something similar to many other shows and so is the overall development of the story. This would have been a deal breaker for me if not for... its romantic sub-plot. This is probably the first time I ever witnessed a romantic sub-plot save a show with a sci-fi school battle setting. This is because this kind of genre is usually linked to the harem tag. And this is where this anime diverges: this is not a harem but it is indeed a romance. 


And you might think "But Trumpcard, how does this change anything ?". A very good question but the difference is actually very important. As much as the main tournament plot is relatively uninteresting, the development of the relationships between the characters is given so much importance and screen time that it makes you care for the characters much more than in any other generic show with generic characters. The way the anime invests time into building emotions helps fleshing out the characters of the show instead of leaving them as walking clichés: this is the main difference between Rakudai and other harem shows and in my opinion, this alone helps improving the story's score from a 4/10 to an 8/10.


Now onto my favourite section: the characters. 


I do say this is my favourite section but as mentioned before, the characters start off as being devoid of their own personality. Take the main girl, Stella Vermillion. From the beginning, she is introduced as a red-haired tsundere princess with twin-tails who happens to be extremely powerful. This type of character is so common in anime that I could barely see the difference between her and just about any other harem female lead. 


Ikki, the main character, is the same. He is a common boy considered as the weakest one. His character design is rather bland with him having brown hair and eyes - your typical Japanese kid, one might say, which makes it easier for the Japanese audience to project themselves onto him. But just understanding WHY he's designed that way doesn't mean that I enjoy that character design myself. 


As you may have understood by now, the characters - at least at the beginning - have nothing going for them. But something that is especially surprising coming from a 12-episodes anime is that these characters actually do have some character development. Of course, this is not on the same level as something you could expect from a 24-episodes anime but it is still an achievement to turn characters that are so bland and dull into ones we actually care about by the end of the story.


Well although I did say that, that only applies to the main characters though. Don't expect the side ones to have any kind of meaningful backstory or character growth (especially the villains / antagonists). 


So to sum up, yet again I would have given the characters a very low score but the meaningful growth they go through in these 12 episodes makes me want to give it a 6/10.


Onto the art & animation. As someone who is rather picky about the artwork, this can literally be a deciding factor for me as to whether or not to watch a show. To keep it short, the artwork used in Rakudai is something that is very pleasing yet unusual. It reminded me a lot of the one used in No Game No Life, which I also happened to enjoy. If anything, I would put it up there in my list of best artworks used in anime.

The artistic direction used in the OP and the last couple of episodes was very creative and fitting. The use of monochrome scenes coupled with one other single colour helped outlining the emotions conveyed through the scenes.


The animation was also actually pretty good. After visiting Reddit, I found out that people were claiming that the animation of Asterisk Wars was better than the one used in Rakudai. To these people, allow me to laugh for a few seconds before carrying on with this review.


Ha, ha, ha.


There we go. Just so you know, overusing badly timed CG doesn't make for a good animation, people. I don't want to talk too much about another anime in this review so I won't go into comparisons but let me just say that gorgeous artwork coupled with very fluid battle animations and decent normal-scenes animation makes up for something that is a feast for the eyes. 10/10.


The soundtrack was there. It's nothing to write pages about. It was enjoyable yet barely noticeable and didn't really leave an impact on me but at least it wasn't something that destroyed the mood whenever it was inserted. I found the ED rather common but fitting and the OP... well that's either a love or hate. I personally loved it and sang along when it played out but I can see why people would dislike that kind of music. Well, to me any OP that I don't skip every episode is a success and I never skipped this one so I guess it did its job. Thus this section is awarded an 8/10.


As you might have guessed by now from the tone of this review, I started Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry with the expectations of being disappointed by another generic show. And while it is true that this show could be much better if a little more time was invested into a better plot, I actually found myself to be eagerly awaiting for the release of a new episode every week - something that did not happen with Asterisk Wars. When a show makes me wait like that every week, I can't help but award it the maximum enjoyment score: 10/10.


It also made me want to read the light novel and the manga, again something Asterisk Wars completely failed to do. The only other complain about this anime I have at this point is that Asterisk Wars has been confirmed to get a second season while this one has not. I guess people in Japan have different tastes than people in MAL. Gotta blame it on A-1 Picture's mainstream popularity.


Finally, Tale of the Worst One is a show that I would recommend to anyone who's bored of the same old recycled formula in terms of high-school battle shows but still keeps watching them every season... wait a minute. In fact, if you're one of these people you're probably going to watch the show anyway so why do I bother. 

If on the other hand you're someone looking for a meaningful plot then this is probably not for you. But if you still want to give it a go, you might find yourself to be actually enjoying this, just like I did. 


Thus my overall score for this anime is 8/10. Not because it's very original but because despite having an overused setting with overused characters, it tried its best to deliver something new and enjoyable rather than milking the cash cow. So I praise the effort.

Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is probably my favorite take on the whole superpowered kids competing at school thing. I think because it has a good understanding of what works about that setting. It mostly emphasizes the fights and the goofy character dynamics, until the end when it takes a bit of an ill-advised visit to the drama zone.
The characters have very exaggerated personalities, but I do find some of them likable. Ikki and Alice are pretty good characters, I'd say. Admittedly it's hit and miss; Stella and Shizuku are rather annoying. Although the former has decent interactions with Ikki at least. It's probably for thebest that this anime focuses on just that relationship and dials the harem aspect back compared to usual.


The most unqualified strength this has is the fight scenes, which are very good. Detailed, well animated and fun to watch. They do a good job showing how the various characters' powers play off each other, and it's nice how Ikki wins his fights by observing and outsmarting his opponents. Sometimes the fight scenes take up entire episodes, and that's honestly when the show is at its best.


But you can't give it too many props for the story and characters. This is a slightly above average execution of a very standard premise. Nothing too much more than that.

However, I have to mention that Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry does a fantastic job at building you up for the fights. I'm always on the edge of my seat before, and when those fight scenes actually come. 



If you're like me, and enjoy ecchi/harem/comedy anime, then this one is definitely for you. The ecchi-comedy aspect of this anime is surprisingly well done, as it doesn't fail to turn you on and make you laugh at the same time.

I don't usually write reviews, but when I do, its because an anime deserves a review because it was good.
Personally I thought this anime was a great 12 episode series. It had a little bit of everything that I like from action, to romance, to ecchi even. Only thing it lacked (for me personally) was some good ol' nudity, of which there is close to none. 
Story:
From the get-go it looks like your generic action/harem/ecchi series, but it grows out of it quickly. The story itself is probably the weakest part of the anime, but it services the characters quite well. Its a genericstory that works in bringing together fantasy, romance, and action into a futuristic school setting. Once you settle into the rhythm of the anime around the 3rd or 4th episode you realize that it's not a harem story and you fervently hope he picks the best girl (which is immediately clear from the beginning, but after watching about a million harems with dense MCs who don't pick any girl... you get the idea). So the overarching story here about the MC winning tournaments in a school setting is more or less there just to hold this entire piece together, since the main plot gets pretty predictable after the first couple of episodes, and you basically already know what is going to happen in each fight. Personally its the subplots that bring this story beyond your generic anime. Best subplots are MC v his own father and MC with Best Girl (yes i'm trying hard not to do spoilers). So overall a generic story brings together multiple elements in a well balanced story that also happens to be fresh after watching too many harem animes. 


Art:

Since it is a newer anime (2015), drawing is crisp, animation is fluid. Its pretty hard to tell that it was a 2015 anime when compared to newer animes in 2017. The Art also does well to emphasize the plot, which is the first time I've seen it happen. Using a black-white color scheme to emphasize MC's abilities, the contrast of Blue and Red in the final 2 episodes, and also use of light and shadow really impressed me when I saw it. Only thing i would complain about is that all the characters seem to wear eye shadow regardless of (perceived) gender. Possibly usage as a shadowing technique? I dont know personally I've never been a professional artist by any means so it could just be a technique i haven't encountered before.


Sound:

In anime, the sound is good. quality is clear, adds to the art and story itself, and is quite well matched for the setting and the action. Voice actors are on point, especially for Alice with the blending of general male/female properties. However, Opening song was in my opinion badly casted. The male voice for the song threw me off, and personally did not enjoy his voice as it sounded raspy and uninspiring. The end song i didn't even listen to because the start of the song sounded like screechy horror music. Coupled with some red background while thorns on a vine creeped across my screen, no thanks.


Character:

Ah the best part. One of the biggest things for me is THE MC ISN'T A BLOCKHEAD AND CHOOSES THE BEST GIRL AT THE END OF THE SERIES!! I have seen too many idiot MCs who build a harem instead. On the topic of the MC, he is great. generic storyline of how a weak person turns into a strong hero, but this one has his limits. He also gets a good dosage of character development and happens to overcome the mental limits of his family. Best girl is meh, mostly just cute face with nice tits, but still not too bad. She does flip pretty quick in the first episode from haughty princess to naughty princess, but it was enjoyable. She's definitely a tsun in the beginning but also gets that dosage of character development and finds the guts (notice i didn't say balls which is what i would have said) to reveal her feelings to the MC. There is a gay character but it wasn't overplayed so not too bad and was a good supporting character/counselor-type. Then theres the crazy MC's sister who actually loves him but gets no character development and so is easily the weakest character of them all.


Enjoyment:

Like you may have already seen, this anime blends quite a few categories together, and is quite good at it. None of the parts were overwhelmingly covering the others, but all built into the story quite well. That made this anime enjoyable for me. In addition to it putting together genres that i personally enjoy, it had a good ending with a resolution and piqued my interest in season 2 (WHICH IS COMING FALL 2017 i heard/read).


Overall

10/10 for the full package. Honestly did not think it was that bad, although the lack of nudity was sad. I'd say something along the lines of 3 for story + 3 for characters +2 for art +2 for ecchi equals 10 overall

I will like to start by saying that this anime did a few things that i have never seen done through the anime i have seen. One being when something sexual happens it doesnt go to the "whoops im sorry" or "your a pervert" sense that i have seen lots of time. They took that concept with Ikki and Stella and did it the best way possible. I have respect for the animators and story writers for doing that which makes this anime that much better. Through out the anime i felt happy and connected with the characters and what they were dealing with throughout there time around each other. Nothing seemed repetitive or stall. The world was vibrate and interesting to watch. But i will take about each part and what i liked about each of them.


First the story. I loved this story from the first every scene to the ending. Following Ikki become the knight his family never want him to be and watching Stella go from a know it all character to a very loving character in the end because of everyone around her was very good. Everything the characters did or what had happens in the past moves the story forward and doesnt feel like anything is filler. Everything happens for a reason and not because we want the plot to go forward. The battles to were very good with even story elements coming from them as well to get a better understand of what the characters have gone through to be where they are today. 


Next the art. The art of this anime is very colorful and the colors were very vibrant through out the anime. Each scene had the correct color pallet and tone to them to get a better understanding of how the characters are feeling or how the characters movements can be seen with the colors shown. The backgrounds are also something to not look away from. You can still see the characters and what there designs are like and still get a feel of the environment and how they are connecting the overall feel for each of the scenes and moments happening in front of your eyes. You look away for one moment on you might miss the beautiful art the comes across the screen.


Next the sound. Each swing of a sword, each power being used, something hitting the characters or the ground, the music, every bit of sound you hear is connected to what is happening and is not sloppy at all. They get the sounds for combat just right and each movement either fast or slow has its sound with it and not missed. The music as well really helps with the overall tone as well. In the combat, in there rooms, even what happens in Episode 11 and 12. The sounds they use get you more connected to whats happening and what you think might happen next to keep you excited. 


Now for the characters. I have talked about the characters a lot already but this is where i can go all in with them. Ikki is a amazing protagonist and puts others before himself and still able to reach his goal of becoming a knight. He is someone you can connect to in one way shape or form to get better at something and not let others drag you down. Stella at first was a character no one would of liked, but as the anime went on she became more and more likable and would also help out the other characters with what they were doing while also focusing on what she wants to improve upon. Of course the other characters like Shizuku, Alice, and Ayase, all have character development as well and no one is left with just a boring personalty. Each one has something that makes them unique and different from everyone else which i do enjoy in an anime as well. Also the loving relationship that blossoms from Ikki and Stella is really good as well. 


Finally my enjoyment of the anime. Like i said i loved every minute of this anime and i would really wish to see a second season of it and see where they would go with the story and characters. Do somethings need to improve? Of course nothing is every perfect, but if i can have the same enjoyment from this show again with more story progression then i would be so happy to see that. 


Overall im very glad to have seen this because i really enjoyed watching this all the way through. If a second season ever does get made i will be so happy to be able to see more of everyone and everything from this world.

Warning:  Abnormal review ahead!
So picked this up thinking it was going to be another cookie-cutter, single season, harem/action/school show.  And sure enough it hit all my expectations - then smacked me upside the head with "This is how it's done."
All the tropes, cliches, and whatnot's are there.  We have the swimsuit episode, we have the "d...d....d...date?" episode, the tsundere and the sibling complex.  The "stare, stare, stare", the "the enemy of my enemy is my friend" moments each time a new harem member is introduced.
So yea, exactly what you'd expect.  But wait!  There's more!
The characters themselves throw caution tothe wind and tweak their roles just a bit.


The Tsundere?  Yea she calms down pretty quick and figures out that she's being annoying (of course she forgets this lesson the next episode) and actually appologizes on occasion.


The Harem?  Yea it's one sided.  From episode 3 on, it's quit clear who the best girl is.  The MC treats all the other girls as a normal person would.  The 'Harem' tag really should be replaced with 'Romance'.


The MC?  When he inevitably sees the female protagonist in her underwear, instead of being a pansy and claiming he didn't see anything, he grows a pair and acknowledges that he saw, and he liked what he saw.  But he really is sorry for the invasion of privacy.


More MC?  Yea he's the kindhearted fool who goes out of his way to help people (specifically damsels in distress), but he does so with out the melodramatic whining seen in other MCs.  While he is OP, his OPness is actually explained and justified.


Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry takes the genre (harem/action/school) and makes it more realistic (as much as a shonen can be).  It's not going to win awards and accolades, especially as it came out at the same time as a similarly plotted anime, but it does things differently enough to warrant attention.


I'd recommend this show to anyone looking for a light hearted rom/com.

This anime starts off strong, devolves into incomprehensible mess and then sorta recovers in the last episodes.
I honestly thought that the first two episodes are amazing, because they had some sort of spark in them and displayed great chemistry between characters. Unfortunately, that chemistry quickly disappeared, and the series turned into a string of drawn out episodes full of melodramatic events, deus ex machinas, and overdramatizations.
The anime shares a lot of similarities with Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei. The basic idea is the same - a very powerful underdog unjustly mistreated based on arbitrary ranking system. Heck, protagonists even look similar to each other, although Rettosei'smain character had less character and was much more powerful.  The anime also loves putting characters through pointlessly dramatic painful events for no reason, and those situations  feel forced. Sometimes characters just flat out act like idiots. However, with all that in mind, anime looks good, and art style is interesting to watch. The anime uses some sort of soft thin lines, which is slightly different from most of the titles I remember. Main Heroine despite being stereotypical tsundere (with all the blushing, getting upset over nothing, etc), is occasionally itneresting to watch purely from animation angle. Fights feature a lot of movement too... all that is overshadowed by shrotcomings and weak stories of the middle episodes, however.


Either way, detailed breakdown is below:

Story:

Starts strong, gets bad, sorta recovers in the last episode to a tolerable levels. The story suffers from attempts pointless overdramatization, and even though it is supposed to be a one complete whole centered around the tournament, if you look back at it, it feels quite disjointed. Premise is quite similar to Mahouka Koukou no Rettosei, even though the world is not well thought out. There were plenty of situations where events feel forced or the story tries to go out of its way to put characters through some "overly dramatic" event (with onlookers badmouthing character in one frame, and then cheering them in the next), thankfully it does not go as far as Re: Zero went with its "Almost torture porn" episodes.


Art:

Pleasant style which is a bit unusual. Thin lines, soft palette, although I think there were two semi-cg dragons I didn't quite like. OVerall it is of an above average quality, and looks greate after abominably bland backgrounds I've recently seen in High School DxD Born.


Sound:

Decent, but nothing I managed to remember. Complements the story, but doesn't get in your way.


Characters:

Initial strong introduction made me thing there will be well-written interactions between characters with strong chemistry between them. Well, the anime happily proved me to be wrong. There are couple of amusing characters, but in general a lot of characters are inconsistent, and occasionally they act in not very smart or hard to believe fashion. Probably in order to cope with another ridiculous plot device. At the very least, their designs are interesting, and I enjoyed few brief scenes with "Yuri-chan". She was probably the best character in the whole anime. 


Enjoyment:

First two episodes were interesting, portion of the last episode was alright, the rest was quite bland.


Overall:

It could've been better. Might be worth checking out to see the art style, and maybe first two episodes, and maybe the first scene with "Yuri-chan", but story-wise and character-wise the anime doesn't offer much - events are overly dramatic, overly melodramatic, characters often act in weird fashion, and as a result, the whole thing looks fairly hard to believe and disjointed.

The story starts by introducing Blazers AKA Magic users and ranks them based on their magical ability. The MC, Kurogane Ikki a "talentless" F-Rank student opens the story by giving a backdrop of his life as a talentless boy and how he ran away from home because he was ignored because of his state.
What turns from a relatively generic and acceptable opening is soon complimented by a comedic ecchi / service scene. Naturally openings like these are funny and captivate the audience.
"The Worst One" nicknamed Ikki, will challenge "The Best One", Stella, for what originally was room-ground-rulecontrol, that became total control over the other person's life of servitude.

Overall Rating : 4

OST: 7

Art: 8 -> 6 as the show goes on the quality goes down, until the final episode.


The MC is LITERALLY a carbon copy of Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei's Shiba Tatsuya. A seemingly useless mage on pen and paper with extraordinary physical fighting skills that outweigh all other things on the surface. 


Oddly enough his "only" skill, Blade Steal enables him to have outstanding analytical skill EXACTLY the same way as Mahouka's Tatsuya is able to read movement and predict enemy habits with incredible accuracy.


His biological sister, who has strong romantic feelings for her brother ALSO USES ICE MAGIC AS WELL.  


BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE!


Ikki, JUST like Tatsuya is considered useless and without purpose(although Tatsuya was a body-guard/weapon instead), Ikki his considered nothing to his family while his sister is talented beyond belief.


There are so many glaring similarities to Mahouka's plot-line it just makes it worse that the story takes the exact same road where it tries to redeem the strength of the MC, even though that is not what he's trying to prove to everyone, but his father alone.(Mahouka's MC has no care for anyone or anything but his sister, and aspires to be an engineer to improve the world instead)


On top of all this, the show throws in copious amounts of service/ecchi that is completely unneeded almost constantly.


I watched this start to finish hoping it would get better, and it didn't. The antagonists of the show try to make Ikki look worthless, and it obviously, fails to do so.


The final fight however was great. Not gonna even try to break it down. It's not your typical fight, but the way the fight "evolves" start to finish was pretty amazing.


I will not be continuing this series if another season comes out. The show was a train-wreck that ended on a decent fight. I'd like to leave it at that. 


If you're here for a shitty carbon copy plot of Mahouka with a ton of unneeded service and a never-evolving plot-line, and an incredibly shitty romance that escalates faster than the speed of sound, this is the show for you.


If not, don't bother with this.

Hopefully this review helps some people, but it is my first attempt at one so not really sure if it will. Anyway, I have read quite a few reviews where people analyze the art and sound and stuff which is always cool, but I am not a big connoisseur of these things, so I will only touch on them briefly. I will go through the usual breakdown of each category with my own at the end where I will talk about how the anime is with respect to its main genres.
Overview:
I freakin' loved this anime. I texted my friend after the last episode explaining thatI could not stop ejaculating after completing the series (not really, obviously) because it was just...that...good. I am a huge fan romance anime. They are always my go-to and having action with it is a huge bonus. As someone who can not STAND when anime beat around the bush and drag shit out, especially romantically, this anime is absolutely perfect for me. Now you may be asking why not give it a 10/10 then, well just shut the fuck up and read I will get to that, or just skip to the bottom because that is where I will talk about it. Anyway let's get into the nitty-gritty stuff:


Story (8/10):

I personally loved the story of this anime. It was only meant to be 12 episodes so obviously you can not expect much, but I was legitimately interested in the story when there was one. The main character (Ikki, as Stella so kawaii-y calls him) has a life problem and the determination to solve it, great, love it. Short, sweet, simple, good stuff. Moving on.


Art (9/10):

Like I said I am not a big artsy-fartsy guy. I like most art styles, from "Bakemonogatari", to "katanagatari", to "ping pong the animation". This art style was good old-fashioned anime art. It was crisp enough to make the ecchi parts outstanding so it had to be good...right?


Sound(8/10):

Listen...the way I see it if I don't notice the soundtrack then it means it's blended so well into the mood of the moment that it does not stand out, which is what happened with this anime. I would give it a higher grade but that Engrish in the opening ruined a perfectly good song in my opinion. Can't stand Engrish (most of the time).


Character (10/10, easiest decision of my life):

From the very beginning I loved Ikki and Stella. How could you not just fall in love with them after their first encounter (do not want to give away anything, but it is hilarious and amazing)? Stella is an amazing counterpart to Ikki. She is pretty sexual on the outside but a bit shy and reserved on the inside, worried what Kurogane (Ikki's last name) might think of her. Kurogane seems reserved and focused on the outside (which he is), but is actually pretty much a teenage horn-dog at heart. Even the side characters are great. Alice is mysterious and just genuinely intriguing, Shizuku (please let that be her name I was way too focused on Stella in this series) turned out to be a fuckin' bad ass and just an overall cool person. Then there's the perpetually-vomiting professor, the caring-but-stern father, really it was one of the few anime in recent history that I have seen that did not have a single character that just annoyed the shit out of me. The development is pretty fast-paced but not in a way that seems rushed, just overall the characters are awesome, that's all you need to know. 


Enjoyment (10/10):

I'm at half-chub just writing this review, god damn this anime is so good.


Overall (9/10):

I do not give out 10s so easily, so here is my breakdown:


For the purpose of reviews I want to be methodical, so let's analyze each of the main genres: Romance, Ecchi, Action.


Romance:

It is rare that a 12-episode anime has a fantastic romantic aspect like this one. There was no fuckin' around (in more way than one), they just got straight to the point, right out of the gate. Both Stella and Kurogane knew what they wanted and were not coy about it. I personally have gotten sick of the suspense built up in romance anime, cheers to Rakudai Kishi for breaking the trend. 


Score: 10/10

Composition: 60% (meaning I believe the anime is 60% romance)


Action:

For all of the romance in the anime I almost forgot that it is also technically an action anime. Some of the action scenes were rather lacking but there were also some scenes that I still talk about with my friends weeks after the episode it appeared in, they are that bad-ass. Can't ask for everything in such a short season, so the action clearly to a backseat to the romance, which I love, but it did hamper the action aspect for those of you not as into romance as I am.


Score: (8/10)

Composition: 30%


Ecchi:

Surprisingly there was not a ton of ecchi in this anime. Personally, I am not a huge fan of overly-echhi anime. You know the ones, where at one point you just go "oh come on that's just excessive! There should not be tits in this scene! I'm not gonna complain but still, come on!" I was also a huge fan that the ecchi scenes stuck to one character, Stella. It made sense, it was rewarding, and there was not too much of it. The balance was great, and that is the key to a good ecchi.


Score: (9/10)

Composition: 10%


Now to calculate the overall score.

10(.6)+8(.3)+9(.1)

=9.3/10


I can not bring myself to round up from a 9.3, so I had to round down.


In the end, overall score: 9.3/10


Seriously if this gets another season I will weep. Hope you enjoyed my first review, stay classy everyone!

In the pursuit of killing boredom and fulling a rather interesting self-pledge to watch all (Y2k+) rom-coms out there, I bumped into this one evening when deciding to pick out my list for the Fall 2015. This was a pleasant surprise. Having the marks of cliche all over it, I still used the "3 shows and your out rule". Getting over all of the unpleasant rom-com/harem cliches the first episode, this series proved to be a gem. Lets get into it...
Story (7)
As far as stories go, this is a needle in a needle stack. Having the male MC turn out to be the "worst"in a school for  because he has no "talent" (at least the talent the school grades on). The romance subplot complements the action story well, a rare find these days, and to top it off, it does not end like 99% of the rom-com/harems out there. I may imply that cliches are a bad thing, but only if they are done in the most boring way possible. This story presents all of the story elements we are use to, in a new package, with new paint, making it seem like a different toy altogether. I can safely praise the use of well known story elements for they have been used in their best form.


Art(9)

Probably the strongest element in Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry. The fight scenes were very well animated, the characters were distinguishable from more than just their hair styles and colors, and each character had their appearance match their personality in a mostly non stereotypical way. Since this ties into the character element as well, just got to say, well done Silver Link and Nexus.


Sound (6)

Not very memorable but did not pull from the show. Nothing really stands out, good or bad.


Character(8)

In my opinion the art and character elements played very nicely with each other in this series. The characters behaved and acted how you expected, while giving very nice surprises here and there, just like real people. The interactions between the characters were well thought out, as each seems to have an impact later in the series. Most of the "main" supporting roles had good screentime to flesh out their motivation or enhance their flair. The biggest disappointment for me would be the lack of background for Stella, but with 12 episodes and a promising feel for a second season, it does not pose too much issue.


Enjoyment(9) 

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this series. It filled the "week to week gotta see this when it comes on" feeling that Overlord left in its wake. Since series tend to give off a different vibe when you marathon it, I will post an update on that after the Winter Season to ensure that the hype from it died down and I forgot at least some of the inner workings of the plot.

Rakudai Kishi no Cavalry is no way a special or a Masterpiece. This anime is definitely an interesting one when it comes to my overall enjoyment. I have watched eight episodes so far and I can see the development is good and still ahead.
